title: What will be Facebook's end-of-day market capitalization on 31 May 2022?
possible_answers: More than $850 billion but less than $1.10 trillion
preds: Call option 3/6 strike 220 is currently quoting at 8 cents. Re-doing my prev calc gives the prob of exercise ~ 1%.
Limited potential catalysts for upside between now and may 31st. Given that current market cap is roughly 480 billion, updating likelihoods.

At the time of writing,  FB is trading at ~ $191 with a market cap of ~ $518 B. This implies an appreciation of 16% to get to $600 B which in turn implies a price of $221. A call option with a strike of 220 with an expiry of June 3 is trading at $0.41. Using a simplified version of Black-Scholes, C = N(d2) * K - N(d1) * S, where S = current stock price, K = Strike, N(d1) is the delta = 0.0593 & N(d2) is probability of exercise. We want N(d2) N(d2) = 0.0533. So the second bucket should be about 5%.
It will take a major change in sentiment to cause a 15% increase in less than three weeks.  It's not impossible, but it's a long shot.
The crowd seems about right and lines up pretty closely with my simulation results.

For FB's value to climb to $600B in the next 80 days requires an annualized rate of return of over 100%.  If anybody really thinks that is likely they should be buying FB now.  If you've done so I wish you luck -- it could happen.  But I'll bet against it.

This has become more about market direction than Facebook's performance, which itself is a mix of rates, inflation and Ukraine. Meta is currently 10% below 600m so the status quo is bucket one and therefore in a two month period most likely (as a 10% move would itself be - just about- material) .  It is well beyond my capabilities to make confident short term stock market forecasts but that is what is now required for this question. My guess is that markets have been slow to grasp the impact of the Ukraine war and that there is more downside in the next 2 months than upside. However, a fast resolution to the war would probably lead to a bump in markets that may enable Meta to climb into the >600m bucket.

As of writing this forecast FB's market cap is sitting at ~$572.914 Billion USD. If we use this to figure out what kind of gains would be needed to hit each of the bucket posts we get the following: $600 Billion / $572.914 Billion * 100 ~= 104.7% or about a 5% increase over 3 months.
$850 Billion / $572.914 Billion * 100 ~= 148.4% or about a 48% increase over 3 months.
$1.1 Trillion / $572.914 Billion * 100 ~= 192% or about a 92% increase over 3 months.
$1.35 Trillion / $572.914 Billion * 100 ~= 235.6% or about 135% increase over 3 months. If we amortize the average index return (I will use 10% as an estimate for yearly Nasdaq returns for calculation purposes) over the 3 month period being discussed we get a benchmark index return of about 2.5% over 3 months. So therefore when establishing a base case if we were to assume average market returns for FB over the 3 month period we would expect the market cap to be ~$587 Billion dollars. This base case puts us just a little under the first post. This means any reason to think FB may do equal or worse than the index would put it in the lowest bucket, but any reason to think it should outperform should be thought of pushing the base case into the second bucket. To be able to justify pushing the outcome into the 3rd, 4th, or 5th bucket would require massive outperformance (with the stock needing to return at an annualized rate of ~192% to reach the 3rd bucket, ~368% to reach the 4th bucket, and ~540% to reach the 5th bucket). With all this being said, lets look at what we think may actually happen given the state of the market. Looking at the chart of FB we see it is currently in the middle of a massive drawdown reaching about 50% off it's ATH. By my estimation this is the result of a couple things: 1) Growing distrust about it's core FB product's business model (Slowing growth among youth, changes to iOS making ad targeting more difficult, a series of public backlashes about how it handles moderation and disinformation)
2) Uncertainty around it's new 'Meta' ambitions (Appears to be a while until profitability with losses for years being directed into R&D, will this actually be the next big thing or just a passing fad?, etc)
3) A general compression of multiples across the tech sector as people deleverage presumably in preparation for further rate hikes. Not directly related to FB, more of a market wide response to the threat of higher rates. While there are some execution questions about how the company will be able to pivot it's focus away from it's traditional flagship product to something new, I don't think any of these headwinds fundamentally change the outlook of the company. They still are still making massive amounts of profits that they are able to funnel back into the business and they are still able to attract and retain the type of talent to be able to support just about any ambitious R&D goals that they have. As these headwinds are processed and accepted by investors I would expect to see a regression towards the mean as investors start to see the company as a value play when compared to it's mega cap tech peers. The added possibility of a return to Mega tech equities generally adds to to the possibility of outperformance. Because of these reasons to expect reasonable but not other worldly outperformance I am making 2nd bucket my most likely case, with small (2%) chance of a reflexive reversal (Likely cause by derivative traders getting caught offside) that drives the stock way higher than expected, and a moderate (25%) chance of near index average returns or even losses if the situations prove more damaging longterm than I expect.

From current position - stock needs to rise more than 87% to reach market value over $1.1 Trillion. Over the next few months - with large scale geopolitical uncertainty, potential for rising rates, and large amounts of sell offs in the broader market due to inflation - I see a very small chance that this threshhold is reached again in the next 3 months. Raising estimates for the bottom two tiers drastically to account for recent volatility, but not fully moving away from the chance of a rebound especially if Q1 numbers beat expectations.
To stay below 600b, FB needs to stay below 220/share. Hard to know what the future holds here, but I think a rebound is still decently possible.

Adjusting to reflect the ongoing, significant drop in stock price/market cap. So far, the current drop is of comparable size to the short-lived October and late November drops. Possible (and in my opinion, a bit more likely) that we’re near the bottom of another one of those, and market cap will soon stabilize back in bin #3, where it’s been for most of the recent past. This kind of thing seems to represent jitters about an uncertain future more than any specific structural issue. Alternatively, we could be at the beginning of something more like the September drop, which was much larger, and from which market cap has yet to recover. I can’t identify a clear driver for why such a scenario would be occurring, but I’m no industry insider. In this scenario, a bin #2 or even bin #1 outcome would most likely occur.

library(dplyr)
library(readr)
library(quantmod)
company<-"FB"
mktcap<-getQuote(company, what = yahooQF(c("Market Capitalization")))[,2] * 10^-9
stDt <- as.Date(Sys.time())
endDt <- as.Date("2022-05-31")
expctdAnnRtrn<-0.03
r<-exp(log(1+expctdAnnRtrn)/365)-1
remainingCloses<-sum(!weekdays(seq(stDt, endDt, "days")) %in% c("Saturday", "Sunday"))
forecastBands <- c(-Inf,600,850,1100,1350,Inf)
histData<-read_csv(
paste0(
"https://query1.finance.yahoo.com/v7/finance/download/"
, company
, "?period1=946684800&period2="
, floor(as.numeric(as.POSIXct(Sys.time())))
, "&interval=1d&events=history&includeAdjustedClose=true"))
pricehistory<-as.numeric(histData$`Adj Close`)[!is.na(histData$`Adj Close`)]
sdMovementRatio <- sd(log(pricehistory[1:length(pricehistory)-1]/pricehistory[2:(length(pricehistory))]))
simulation<-mktcap*replicate(10000,cumprod(exp(rnorm(remainingCloses,mean = r, sd = sdMovementRatio)))[remainingCloses])
cutSimulation<-as_tibble(cut(simulation,forecastBands))
mutate(count(cutSimulation,value),n/sum(n))

Although not impossible - In the current environment (Rising rates, still some pandemic uncertainties, talks of regulation) this is highly unlikely, especially with poor performance from 'Index Mates' that can also pull the price down.  I still believe it is more likely than not that the company will increase from the current price over the next ~4 months and reach the 850 Bn limit (current .8% below) which is in line with the highest rating. It will be interesting to see the scope/duration of the current slump.

I haven't updated on this question probably for too long. Lowering bin 4 but not ruling it out as much as the crowd; last year, Meta's market cap rose ~20% in the period between mid Jan and the end of May, and a similar rise could put Meta's stock price in bin 4. Also, if interest rates rise, stock prices could fall, too, so I don't rule out bin 2. On the off-chance that Sec 230 is revised as a consequence of the Jan 6 commission's findings, I'll leave a small weight on the first bin.

Updating given the changing rate environment in the US. At writing the FB market cap is $927B and I suspect this year will be lacklustre for tech, given the Fed's hawkish rate tilt. For FB to hit bucket three or four (>$1.1T) we'd need a 20% rally from here to end of May which seems less likely if the Fed hikes. I'll need to do mroe work to see if/when FB has rallied >20% in 5 months. With that said, I do think the smaller-cap, less profitable tech names will face the brunt of the selling, which could draw fund flows into FB, which is reasonably attractive on a relative valuation basis, so this could counter the macro "sell tech" sentiment. Risk is to the downside it feels (and increasingly hawkish Fed) so I'm adding a few more points to the second bucket.

140 days until May 31st, e.g. about 4 and a half months. For most of the last 4 months, Facebook's stock price has held steady around a mean of about 325 and 2.782b shares outstanding for a total market cap of 930.137b, where I'll assume it'll stay (the middle bucket) unless news breaks, which makes things pretty nice and simple. All things considered, history seems to indicate that Facebook's stock will go up. For the past three years, on average, it's gone up at a rate of about half a percentage point per week. If it were to continue to increase on trend, that would take the price up to about 1 trillion exactly. Over that time frame, the most Facebook's stock has ever fallen in a short time is by 30%, back when the lockdowns began. I think we can safely consider that a reasonable worst-case scenario for a news-based drop, at least at this early stage in the game. That would take us down to 234/share, or $651 billion. Dropping below $850b would mean The stock price dropping by 10%, or back down to about 300, which it almost touched earlier this week and which it saw as recently as August. Boy, that seems decently likely! I think a continuation of previous trends is more likely than legislation that happens to hit the sweet spot where it'll make the price dip, and I'll pay some lip service to the other buckets here.
The current capitalization growth seems linear to me. I don't think it will reach $1.10 trillion before June. Facebook has good fundamentals. The stock price may already reflect the current scrutiny.
meta is going to have a heyday i think (esp if any sort of crash is incoming), but i'm having a hard time imagining how long it'll last,

Meta(!) is growing revenue between 30 and 50% each quarter (on the previous quarter) and is valued at 13.5x EBITDA (approximately, and <7x revenues). Apple and Microsoft are values >22x EBITDA and Google >15x. Meta would most likely fall if the whole market does and form today a 20% fall would push the value into the 600-800 bucket, however if there is a gain before a fall then the valuation may well stay above 850 (e.f. 10% gain then 18% fall) and so I put the probability of a fall below 850 fairly low (even though I am bearish on markets this year). If Meta grows as normal (by end May we will see 4Q and 1Q results) the valuation should rise and has considerable room to do so as Meta is the least highly valued of its peer group. A c15% rise pushes the value into the 1.1-1.35 bucket, the status quo is 850-1.1.

At pixel the current market cap is $884bn. Let's assume the market stays flat to close out the year, given recent turbulence / strong run. FB's 5-yr CAGR is ~30%. Let's use this as our base rate for 2022, but you're only getting 40% of the year (Jan-May) so we'll give the base rate 12% growth. That puts us at $990bn. So my base case puts us right in option three. With that said, FB is a laggard of the "Big Tech" group and may deserve a catch-up trade. Plus it does have the metaverse tailwinds. Even if we add +10% to our forecast we stay within option three. Further, given the Fed's hawkish pivot and the negative impact higher rates may have on tech names, I have to reign in my upside scenarios for the name. This is my first stab -- I'll have to re-evaluate after year-end and further Fed meetings.
Adjusting forecast to account for the ongoing, steep drop. Still plenty of time for new developments, though.

Adjusting to reflect elapsed time.
Noteworthy that the “whistleblower” saga and big rebranding to “Meta” do not seem to have dimmed the longer-term view, as share prices have been rising again at pre-Sept. rates (or even higher) for more than a month now, heading towards exceeding the current record price perhaps sometime in Feb.-Mar. 2022. If status quo growth rates continue all the way through May, then we should be firmly in bin #4 territory.
However…the economy as a whole and development of the Omicron variant globally in particular seem like major wildcards (among many other unknowns, of course). Potential Fed actions to stop inflation, war between Ukraine and Russia, oil market shenanigans by OPEC, resource shortages or further supply chain issues etc. could all potentially drive major new market shocks / corrections that would keep FB market cap in its current #3 bin throughout the timeframe of interest. I am having a hard time seeing a case where no new problem in the world economy hits the overall stock market levels in our timeframe. 
Finally, always a lingering chance that further revelations of intentional wrong-doing or bad impacts on society caused by FB could  cause sharp drops in market cap (bin #2).

The data are so noisy, so I'm projecting a wide cone of uncertainty around an upward trend amplified by a bit of inflation. I don't think the market cap will likely be lower than it is today, but large shocks to the stock market or to FB can never be ruled out.

The FB stock is reasonably priced with for example a p/e in the low twenties. So absent of a big market crash or (another) big public scandal for the company, the stock price should be able to at least retain current levels. It should be a relative inflation proof business and even though a rise in interest rates can affect the FCF models, the company doesn't have a debt problem and the underlying business is good. On the other hand, I don't expect huge growth in the this time period and their metaverse play won't come to fruition any time soon.

I calculate the intrinsic value of Facebook to be around 1.4 trillion based on many factors such as revenue, earning growth, competitive advantages, competitor analysis, and interest rate. Its network effect is unlikely to be defeated very quickly, and will likely remain for years. Its revenue growth is estimated at 20% by looking at the trend in previous years (need to consider pre-pandemic growth trend since the pandemic is a non-repeatable event that accelerates its revenue growth a lot.). Due to negative news and public perception, its stocks may not reach its intrinsic value of 1.4 trillion, but somewhere below it by a margin that is not too big.

FB market cap is currently $925B. Dropping to $850B would require a 9% price drop. That seems possible to me because there is such overwhelming negative sentiment about the company. Dropping to $600B would require a 36% price drop. The only ways I can see that happening is another market-wide panic (unlikely) or an antitrust action (also unlikely but less so than the panic scenario). It's not a matter of whether an antitrust action will happen but rather whether it will happen before 31 May 2022, which is a little less than 7 months from today. I guess that's possible. But even so, would it cause the stock to drop 36%? On the day the MSFT antitrust was decided MSFT was around $36. Its low was around $25 three months later, a 30% drop. So an antitrust action might not even affect the FB share price immediately. Meanwhile it continues to be a very profitable company.

Distribution from a couple Monte Carlo sims, using FB's beta, S&P 500 as benchmark, and projected inflation rate as the risk-free rate.

Subjective interpretation of FB past market cap history. My best guess is that in the time frame of interest, significantly regulating or even “trust busting” FB will probably look like gun control efforts: there will be some newer and more outrageous events/disclosures. Some people will be very angry, including (justifiably!) those who realize that they’ve been taken advantage of or even been put into dangerous physical or psychological situations through use of FB. Then most of the public will go back to their lives, and nothing will change (before 31 May 2022). Things may well evolve in a different direction eventually, perhaps in the next 5-10 years, but this is a fairly short timeframe question, so I’m heavily favoring “status-quo-like” outcomes in this initial forecast.

Outside view:  Generally stocks go up.  Up over 45% seems like a lot in 7 months. Also, a market crash would pull down FB with it.
Inside View: Absent regulation, this controversy will not be the determining factor of FBs market cap in 7 months. Also, I am not convinced regulations will impact stock price too much (FB has lots of lobbyists - so any regulation will likely be light and probably give investors more confidence that these controversies will decrease). If the gov tries to break them up, it wont be done before this resolves (lawsuits).    10% market correction is not unreasonable (why I have $600-$850 so high)
Up 18% seams reasonable, so I split options 3 and 4.
